Handle more invalid token errors for authenticated calls

commit.message:
Tweak docs for token ids.

The broken sentence was clearly because I was working on it while half-asleep.
Add missing default settings from docs.

Allow three states for the token id config.

I think this makes sense, since a UUID is a fairly hefty beast ad not everyone will need them. Thanks to @nigoroll for the suggestion.

This will make using token ids for invalidation a little trickier, but we can warn people that turning this off creates a limitation when we come to that or make them mandatory once we're making them more useful.

Only include the orig_jti on refreshed tokens.

This means that someone who wants the original id for a non-refreshed token would need to read it from the 'jti' claim, but I think that's better than having quite so much redundant data in every original token.

(I'm tempted to do something similar for orig_iat, but I worry that would cause compatibility problems for anyone reading from the claim outside of the library. Also the timestamp is much shorter than a UUID, so it's a much smaller saving.)

Handle more token errors.

There are a number of subclasses of InvalidTokenError that bubble up as unhandled errors in the old code.

I've kept the explicit handling of DecodeError and Expired Signature, which are also children of InvalidTokenError, in order to preserve their distinctive responses.
Add some more tests for error cases with 'bad' tokens.
Add changelog notes for PR 69.

Add a less terse description of when people should turn this on.

I'm guessing a little at the version number this will ship in, but we can always tweak it further.

Add config option to enforce that tokens should have a token id for verification (and original id for refresh).

I think it's preferable to reject these, but for someone upgrading a running service it would be unsafe to start insisting that all tokens have token ids immediately. Having a setting allows the operator to start enforcing it after all of their valid tokens were made by a new enough version of the library, which depends on how they have configured expiration times.

(I need to update the docs once I know which version the jti change will ship in.)
Add check that a new token sets both the token id and original token id to the same value.

Track the original token ID when refreshing tokens.

This allows us to tie any authorized request back to the original authentication event, identified by the original token's ID.

It should also be useful for allowing a stronger blacklist check not just for the token but for any token stemming from the same original token.

Add a JWT ID to the payload.

This is a fairly common optional claim.

I have a case where I want to track audit records back to the associated authentication event, so being able to identify the token reasonably uniquely would be very helpful.

commit.message: Added the missing part about DEFAULT_AUTHENTICATION_CLASSES
Added changelog

Fixes and additions

Fixed spelling error in previous PR and added a section about class-based views in the doc.

Added a section in docs about decorators

JWT and authorization can be a tough topic for beginners to break into. While the documentation clearly outlines the starting places, it has left out the portion for decorators and decorating the to-be-protected views.

commit.message:
When the Authorization header is sent with a different prefix other than
default it raises error.
It should return None so that other class can validate it.

Merge pull request #58 from feanil/feanil/remove_blacklist_token_uniqueness

Remove unique constraint on blacklist.token TextField.

commit.message:
Remove unique constraint on blacklist.token TextField.

In MySQL `TextField` can't have a unique constraint:
https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/2.2/ref/databases/#textfield-limitations

Before this change, trying to run the initial blacklist migration on
MySQL gives the following error:

`BLOB/TEXT column 'token' used in key specification without a key length`

The change removes the database constraint but uses the get_or_create
method to prevent duplication from requests made in parallel.

https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/3.0/ref/models/querysets/#get-or-create

Because the existing initial migration can't be run on MySQL I updated
it to remove the uniqueness constraint.
